ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Introducing: The Creative Thinking Approach
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello Ken, Thanks for the really kind words regarding the Creative Thinking Approach. IÃ†m glad you like it. Please see below for answers to your questions.

Subject: Re: [neat] Introducing: The Creative Thinking Approach
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=7WsVzhJh5Ek3Fb_N4qDVbklcPUBcSMNvIpT0fNxAfThvkXuNivPl
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune
From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>


--Apple-Mail=_E4F7AD4B-E09C-4DBC-BC2A-E3B55BB6E75F
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello Ken,

Thanks for the really kind words regarding the Creative Thinkin=
g Approach. I=92m glad you like it. Please see below for answers to your qu=
estions. 

> Hi Jeff, congrats on the Creative Thinking Approach (CTA) publ=
ication!  It's a great idea that expands elegantly on novelty search and ra=
ises all kinds of interesting questions and possibilities.  It also appears=
 to offer real practical benefits in the difficult tasks you tried, so I'm =
imagine people will be trying it out in their difficult tasks as well.
> 
>=
 
As people try it, please let us know how it works. I=92m eager to hear ho=
w it works in other setups.

> The paper does a good job addressing some of=
 the more immediate questions in its discussion.  I like how you explained =
how it could be extended naturally to NEAT because of the historical markin=
gs.  But going beyond that discussion, I'm curious whether there could be a=
 downside to the fact that adding hidden neurons gives you almost a guarant=
eed novelty bump because of the fact that they would be paired with zeros i=
n any behavior comparison with other networks?  Do you worry that the idea =
might then be a sort of mild bloat amplifier when paired with neuroevolutio=
n algorithms that complexify?  That is, if I can't find something novel to =
do, the cheap way out might be just to get bigger?  Of course, while that's=
 an interesting question to think about, I'm guess it probably doesn't matt=
er much in practice since there is so much other relevant information in th=
e behavior vector anyway.
> 
> 
That=92s an interesting observation that ha=
dn=92t occurred to me. You=92re right that it could cause bloat: it=92ll be=
 interesting to see if that occurs and to what extent. That said, I=92m not=
 too worried about it, because our other research (as you know) is really s=
howing the benefit of a connection cost in terms of boosting performance an=
d modularity (http://youtu.be/Rgq7Jzsw8vw). If you add a connection cost al=
ong with the Creative Thinking Approach, that should override any pressure =
to bloat up just to get a creative thinking bump. 

My guess is that both o=
f these techniques will independently help on most problems, but now you=92=
ve brought up a reason why they especially could work well together. :-)

>=
 At a more fundamental level, I am wondering about the implications of beha=
vior being characterized by inputs and outputs.  But that idea I realize is=
 more related to earlier work of JBM and Stef, so perhaps it really doesn't=
 impact the CTA idea,  That is, I imagine CTA can still work even if the be=
havior characterization is not directly constructed from inputs and outputs=
.  For example, you could still combine a behavior characterization taken f=
rom the absolute trajectory of the robot with the hidden nodes activation l=
evels over time.  It's mixing different types of information, but if you no=
rmalize appropriately I don't think that matters.  What do you think?  Is t=
here something about CTA that somehow needs you to characterize behaviors d=
irectly off of inputs and outputs?  (For example, did you do it that way be=
cause other ways didn't work with it?)
> 
The Creative Thinking Approach co=
uld definitely be mixed withy any behavioral metric, as you point out and y=
our example shows. We did not try that, but I can=92t think of a reason it =
wouldn=92t work. You=92re right that you=92d have to get the relative weigh=
ting right, but that shouldn=92t be hard. We chose to extend  Jean-Baptiste=
 and St=E9phane=92s input-output neural firing metric because the CTA is a =
natural extension of their idea and code base, and because I really like ho=
w general their behavioral metric is. In other words, if it works, I=92d ra=
ther use their behavioral metric first because of how general it is. I=92d =
only want to switch to a human-designed metric if their general, off-the-sh=
elf behavioral metric was not working for some reason. 

> 
> Going back to=
 the implications of characterizing behavior based on inputs and outputs, I=
 understand it has been shown effective, but I worry about whether it might=
 somehow limit possibilities in the future.  For example, the kinds of beha=
viors you get likely depend upon the behavior characterization (that seems =
common sense), so in the future we may discover that different domain-speci=
fic characterizations tend to collect different sets of diverse behaviors. =
 That may not have mattered or proven true so far, but it could matter in t=
he future.  Again I realize this issue likely doesn't matter for CTA anyway=
 since it can use whatever behavior characterization it wants.  So it's mor=
e of a general question.
> 
> 
I agree that different metrics will likely p=
rovide different results. As mentioned above, I like this one because it do=
esn=92t inject an experimenter=92s bias and it doesn=92t take an experiment=
er=92s time, but I=92d naturally start trying different metrics if their of=
f-the-shelf idea didn=92t work. And, as you mentioned, the Creative Thinkin=
g Approach blends nicely with either. 

> Overall it's a clever idea that w=
orked out very well.  And it's nice how you showed it becomes more helpful =
in the more difficult problems. 
> 
Thanks. My guess is that it will defini=
tely work better on harder problems, especially cognitive problems that req=
uire memory, and I look forward to seeing how research into this idea unfol=
ds in the coming years. 

> By the way, is first author Jingyu Li actually =
a high school student?  Is there a story behind that?
> 
She is a high-scho=
ol student! She=92s precocious and is taking many upper-level undergraduate=
 courses, many of which are cross-listed as graduate courses. That means th=
at she=92s frequently learning alongside Ph.D. students. Moreover, she has =
been one of the top students in both of the classes of mine that she has ta=
ken, including those Ph.D. students! She=92s also very hard working and put=
 a lot of effort into this paper. In fact, I frequently forget that she=92s=
 in high-school and instead consider her as simply one of the Ph.D. student=
s in my lab. What=92s also great is that her hard work and talents are not =
going unnoticed. In addition to publishing this GECCO paper, she also recen=
tly won an ACM-Womens scholarship, and received a full ride to MIT, Caltech=
, Cornell, and many other top schools. She=92ll be attending MIT in the fal=
l. 

She=92ll be presenting this paper at GECCO so you=92ll have the chance=
 to meet her in person. She also recently joined this list, so she=92ll pro=
bably really embarrassed by all the praise I=92m heaping on her, but it=92s=
 very well deserved. :-)

Congrats Jingyu!!!!!

Thanks,
Jeff

> 
> Best,
> =

> ken
> 
> 
> 
>  
> 
> 

--Apple-Mail=_E4F7AD4B-E09C-4DBC-BC2A-E3B55BB6E75F

ce since there is so much other relevant information in the behavior vector=

rms of boosting performance and modularity (<a href=3D"http://youtu.be/Rgq7=
